There are a few ways that a smart contract could defend against bad actors who attempt to provide false data in a blockchain-based crowd-sourcing tool for gathering and sharing user-device feedback on coverage information:

1. Use multiple data sources: By collecting data from multiple sources, it becomes more difficult for a single bad actor to manipulate the data. For example, the smart contract could require that data be collected from at least three different users before it is included in the heat map.
2. Implement a reputation system: The smart contract could include a reputation system that rewards users for providing accurate data and penalizes users who provide false data. This could help to incentivize users to provide accurate information and discourage them from attempting to manipulate the data.
3. Use cryptographic techniques: The smart contract could use cryptographic techniques like zero-knowledge proofs or homomorphic encryption to verify the accuracy of the data without revealing the underlying data itself. This could help to prevent bad actors from manipulating the data without being detected.

I hope these ideas are helpful in designing your smart contract to defend against bad actors who attempt to provide false data. Let me know if you have any additional questions or need further guidance.
